body:
### Problem

LSP diagnostic signs disappear one second after entering insert mode, only to reappear after leaving insert mode.

This leads thel code "jumping" when insert mode  is entered due to the sign column disappearing. 

This is the closest thing I could find in the help (the default seems to be what I want, but the behavior is unwanted since diagnostics *are* updated):

    :helpgrep update_in_insert
    update_in_insert: (default false) Update diagnostics in
    Insert mode (if false, diagnostics are updated on
    InsertLeave)

Similar issues:

1. [https://www.reddit.com/r/neovim/comments/10z4q16/lsp\_diagnostics\_disappear\_completely\_in\_insert/](https://www.reddit.com/r/neovim/comments/10z4q16/lsp_diagnostics_disappear_completely_in_insert/)
2. [https://vi.stackexchange.com/questions/42126/neovim-how-to-keep-the-diagnostic-message-in-insert-mode](https://vi.stackexchange.com/questions/42126/neovim-how-to-keep-the-diagnostic-message-in-insert-mode)

### Expected behavior

- No diagnostics should disappear when entering insert mode.
  - (All diagnostics that were shown before entering insert mode should stay visible until insert mode is leaved)
- No new diagnostics should appear while in insert mode.

comment_data.body:
> There is afaik nothing in Neovim that would change the diagnostics on insert enter by default.

Indeed, if by "insert enter" you mean <kbd>i</kbd>, but <kbd>o</kbd> does trigger this issue reliably in LSPs that publish diagnostics before the file is saved.

> My best guess is that if you enter insert mode and type something, the client notifies the server about the document changes and then the server re-publishes the diagnostics.

Yes, that's exactly what happens. The problem is that `lua.vim.diagnostic.show` unconditionally (even if `update_in_insert` is `false`) hides the diagnostics:
https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/50284d07b6f020c819aeb07bfb30d88453e63b6d/runtime/lua/vim/diagnostic.lua#L1464
and then schedules them to be shown after insert mode ends:
https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/50284d07b6f020c819aeb07bfb30d88453e63b6d/runtime/lua/vim/diagnostic.lua#L1477-L1481

The hide should be scheduled as well, not performed immediately.

> Would need some minimal reproduction steps

1. use an LSP that publishes diagnostics while typing (as opposed to only when the file is saved), such as lua_ls
2. set `update_in_insert` to false
3. open a file that has at least one diagnostic somewhere
4. press <kbd>o</kbd>

---

Note: I was quite annoyed by this issue, but even more annoying was the fact that any normal-mode edits (deleting a word, …) would spam me with diagnostics immediately, so locally I have a miniplugin that delays hiding/showing diagnostics until after the file is saved. It happens to work around this bug. Code here: https://github.com/liskin/dotfiles/blob/2e674efcf45140d911ac28fec87dddbb568cf47e/.config/nvim/lua/init/diagnostic_delay.lua
It'd be nice if neovim itself had an option to never update diagnostics until after the file is saved. I should probably open a separate issue for this though.
This has been closed since a request for information has not been answered for 30 days. It can be reopened when the requested information is provided.

comment_data.body: @wookayin can you pls drop the needs: labels so the bot keeps it open?

Reproduction for python with lsp server `pylsp`:

1. install pylsp
2. nvim config:
```vim
call plug#begin(stdpath('data') . '/pylsp_plugged')
Plug 'neovim/nvim-lspconfig'
call plug#end()

lua <<END
local lsp = require('lspconfig')
lsp.pylsp.setup { settings = { pylsp = { plugins = { pylint = { enabled = true }}}}}
END
```
3. Press `o` in second line in a python file with this content (there is a diagnostic from pycodestyle on the last line):
```py
""" This file actually has a docstring """



NUMBER = 100
```

As a workaround that I think I will keep as my default setting because I started liking it, I added this to my config:

```vim
lua vim.diagnostic.config({virtual_text={format=function(d) return "" end}, signs=false})
nnoremap <c-j> <cmd>lua vim.diagnostic.goto_next({float={source=true}})<cr>
nnoremap <c-k> <cmd>lua vim.diagnostic.goto_prev({float={source=true}})<cr>
```

Following code can solve this issue.
```
vim.diagnostic.config({
    virtual_text = true,
    signs = true,
    update_in_insert = true,  // here
    underline = true,
    severity_sort = false,
    float = true,
  })
```

> Following code can solve this issue.
> 
> ```
> vim.diagnostic.config({
>     virtual_text = true,
>     signs = true,
>     update_in_insert = true,  // here
>     underline = true,
>     severity_sort = false,
>     float = true,
>   })
> ```

This is further away from the expected behavior. This issue is about diagnostics *not* updating in insert mode.

> The problem is that `lua.vim.diagnostic.show` unconditionally (even if `update_in_insert` is `false`) hides the diagnostics:
> 
> [neovim/runtime/lua/vim/diagnostic.lua](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/50284d07b6f020c819aeb07bfb30d88453e63b6d/runtime/lua/vim/diagnostic.lua#L1464)

That will lead to "stale" diagnostic signs in insert-mode. Which would be reported as a different bug...

> > The problem is that `lua.vim.diagnostic.show` unconditionally (even if `update_in_insert` is `false`) hides the diagnostics:
> > [neovim/runtime/lua/vim/diagnostic.lua](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/50284d07b6f020c819aeb07bfb30d88453e63b6d/runtime/lua/vim/diagnostic.lua#L1464)
> 
> That will lead to "stale" diagnostic signs in insert-mode. Which would be reported as a different bug...

No, it wouldn't. What happens is that you enter insert mode, do something, the LSP sends new diagnostics, `lua.vim.diagnostic.show` unconditionally calls `hide`, thus making the diagnostic signs disappear immediately, and then since `update_in_insert` is false, it doesn't show the updated diagnostics.

Oh, you mean it would lead to stale diagnostics if this was fixed by not hiding them? Yeah I suppose it would. But then `update_in_insert` might as well be called `hide_in_insert`…

I mean, setting `update_in_insert` to false kinda implies that stale diagnostics is what one wants. What else would you expect to get by disabling the update? I don't see why that would be considered a bug.

> setting `update_in_insert` to false kinda implies that stale diagnostics is what one wants

ok, send a PR :)
